metadata.case_name: Indu Bhusan Chatterjee v. The State

facts.text: Appellant was Assistant Supervisor of Claim Cases of the Bengal Nagpur Railway (Vizianagram Section), later Eastern Railway, with power to deal finally with claims up to Rs. 75 and recommend higher claims to superior officer.
Appellant and V.S. Doraiswamy met in 1950; Doraiswamy working on behalf of persons with claims against the Railway.
Rs. 10 paid to appellant by Doraiswamy in October 1951, and Rs. 15 in January 1952, as gratification for speedy and favourable disposal of claim cases.
On secret information, Deputy Superintendent of Police, Special Police Establishment at Puri directed Inspector G.N. Brahma to contact Doraiswamy regarding alleged dishonesty by railway officials.
Brahma met Doraiswamy and asked him to meet again in Calcutta on May 10, 1952, after filing complaint with letters from appellant.
Permission obtained from Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta to investigate.
Doraiswamy met appellant in Calcutta; settled to pay Rs. 100 on May 12, 1952, at 6 p.m. at India Coffee House.
Doraiswamy informed police; marked ten-rupee currency notes given to him.
Appellant and Doraiswamy met at India Coffee House; talk about expediting claim cases; list of cases given to appellant; bundle of marked currency notes put in appellant's left upper shirt pocket.

Inspectors H.K. Mukherjee, S.B. Mitra, G.N. Ghosh (Assistant Director Postal Services), and Brahma approached appellant; accused him of receiving bribe; appellant produced notes and list after hesitation; numbers tallied.

Appellant convicted under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and s.161 IPC by Special Judge; sentenced to 3 months RI and Rs.500 fine (default 1 month RI) under s.161; no separate sentence under Act.
Appeal to Calcutta High Court dismissed.
High Court certified under Art.134(1)(c) Constitution fit for Supreme Court appeal.
Sanction for prosecution sought from and granted by Mr. R.K. Bokil, Chief Commercial Superintendent, Eastern Railway (PW 5), who was competent.

Bokil stated he went through relevant papers, applied mind, satisfied in interests of justice to prosecute; sanction Ex.6 details demand and acceptance of Rs.100 on May 12, 1952 for speedy settlement.
In cross-exam, Bokil said sanction prepared by police, put by personnel branch; did not call for records or claim cases.
Concurrent findings of fact by courts below not questioned before Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was a valid sanction under s.6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, as the sanctioning authority had applied his mind to the facts and circumstances of the case.

petitioner_arguments.text: No valid sanction under s.6 of the Act as Mr. Bokil did not apply his mind; merely signed ready-made sanction prepared by police; cross-exam shows he did not call for records, connected claim cases or enquire about their position.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King

respondent_arguments.text: Valid sanction as Ex.6 on face discloses application of mind; Bokil went through relevant papers and was satisfied; cross-exam statements do not show lack of application of mind, merely no investigation of truth.

court_reasoning.text: Ex.6 clearly states facts of demand and acceptance of Rs.100 on May 12, 1952 as motive/reward for speedy settlement; states Bokil applied mind and satisfied in interests of justice to prosecute under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanction on face valid; matches charges; no more facts required.

court_reasoning.text: Bokil's exam-in-chief: went through all relevant papers before sanctioning; cross-exam does not contradict as he was not required to investigate truth or call records; papers provided necessary material.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Officer of high rank would not blindly sign; no reason to distrust statement.

court_reasoning.text: High Court certificate granted doubting sanction, but on scrutiny, sanction valid and in keeping with Gokulchand case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanction does not conflict with precedents.

holdings.text: Sanction under s.6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 was valid as sanctioning authority applied mind to facts and circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction in this case in keeping with observations; does not conflict.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (II of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant convicted under s.5(2); sanction required under s.6; offence of criminal misconduct by corrupt/illegal use of position.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of accepting illegal gratification as motive/reward for official act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court certified case fit for Supreme Court appeal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld conviction and sentence, finding valid sanction under s.6 of the Act; concurrent factual findings not disturbed.

key_quotes.text: "before according the sanction he went through all the relevant papers and was satisfied that in the interests of justice the appellant should be prosecuted."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is inconceivable that an officer of the rank of Mr. Bokil would blindly sign a ready-made sanction prepared by the police."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "When the sanction itself and the evidence of Mr. Bokil are carefully scrutinized and read together there can be little doubt that the sanction accorded was a valid sanction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
